description: Denver Post sports columnist Mark Kiszla answered questions about all things Colorado sports in a live chat Monday. Kiz, how big of an impact is Jerry Jeudy going to make for us this year? Kiszla: I'm stoked about Jerry Jeudy.
text:
Denver Post sports columnist Mark Kiszla answered questions about all things
Colorado sports in a live chat Monday. Here are the highlights.

Kiz, how big of an impact is Jerry Jeudy going to make for us this year? Kid
looked amazing last year and everything says he's got the skillset to make it
at the next level.

Kiszla: I'm stoked about Jerry Jeudy. Cannot promise you he will prove to be
the best wide receiver in this draft. But he has definitely got a chance.
Courtland Sutton has Pro Bowl skills, yet I don't think he's quite at the
level of a game-changer. Jeudy could be a game-changer. And if Sutton proves
to be the Broncos' No. 2 pass-target, then quarterback Drew Lock will be a
very happy man.

Why are you so against John Elway and his draft picks? It seems that every
time he makes a pick you are the first one to say, huh, what was he thinking?
Are you really that set against taking KJ Hamler in the second round?

Kiszla: Well, I just said I was stoked about Jeudy. Said it before the draft,
gave it a big thumbs up on opening night of the draft. So maybe you're fudging
about my evaluation. But you're right about one thing: Unlike many sports
journalists in this dusty old cowtown, I don't kiss Mr. Elway's rings. Through
the years I've bashed Elway for taking Brock Osweiler rather Russell Wilson in
the draft (how'd that turn out?) and I praised Elway for drafting Paxton Lynch
(my bad). I told ya Royce Freeman was reach and got really excited about
Phillip Lindsay from the instant he signed with the team as a free agent. My
colleague Ryan O'Halloran, who certainly knows his football, enthusiastically
gave Elway an "A" grade for the 2020 draft. I thought Elway lost his way on
Day 2. I was fond of Hamler as player at Penn State, as I mentioned prior to
the draft. But on a team that could use help immediate help in the secondary,
I don't see Hamler getting a lot of touches as a rookie in this offense.

Why are the Dodgers so much better than Rockies at drafting and developing
young players?

Kiszla: The Rockies want you to believe the Dodgers buy their championships.
The money helps. But the Dodgers also have flexed more brainpower in the
draft. That the Rockies have not been able to draft and develop a replacement
for Todd Helton at first base is beyond perplexing to me. (And that's me being
nice.) But in a Broncos town, the baseball sins and misdeeds in LoDo are
quickly forgotten or downright ignored by the masses. And when somebody like
me points them out, I'm often told to sit back and enjoy the sunshine at Coors
Field, because fretting about the final score shouldn't matter. This is not a
demanding baseball town. Cool by me. As we've seen lately, this town has far
bigger problems than where the Rockies wind up in the standings.

Hey Kiz, thanks for the chat. MLB says 80 games. MLBPA proposes 114 with games
going into November. I can't wait to see the Red Sox and Yankees game on
Thanksgiving. The players want closer to full salary and a year of service
time, in the latter case even if a player decides to stay at home. Then they
get to repeat the dance around the CBA soon after. While do you think are the
cooler heads, and is there a reasonable chance we'll see meaningful baseball
any time soon?

Kiszla: Major-league baseball needs to buy a vowel  and a clue. I don't have
time for no stinkin' money spat in a country where there are riots in the
streets, shuttered businesses and grandmas and grandpas afraid to breathe, let
alone go outside.No that being said, I think the financial burden should fall
more on franchise owners than players to resume the season. But suggesting MLB
try to squeeze in 114 regular-season games in 2020 seems out of touch with
reality. Will cooler heads prevail? I hope so. But I'm not counting on it.

Kiz, it looks like the Avs are favored to win the Stanley Cup if the season
truly returns. What says you?

Of the major pro sports, which are you most excited to see return and why?

Kiszla: Well, America needs its football. They call this Broncos Country, not
Avs Country. I understand and respect that. But, from a local perspective, I
want to see how far Nikola Jokic or Nathan MacKinnon can go in the playoffs.
To tell you the truth, if the Rockies do not take the field in 2020, I will
feel empathy for folks who love baseball. But I will not miss the Rockies for
even half a heartbeat if a money squabble means there will be no baseball and
20th and Blake this year.

Why does the Denver media kiss Elway's butt? He's been an awful GM for 5 years
now. Vegas has them at 7.5 wins. Drafts have been terrible except for 2
players in 2018 and maybe 3 in 2019, but before that was sooo bad. But now
he's drafting team captains that can't start, so he's really found his stride.
Nationally the Broncos are an afterthought with no owner. Is the Denver media
blind?

Kiszla: Well, follow the money. If a media outlet is a business partner with
the Broncos, then the money limits the amount of criticism and objectivity
that can be broadcast/telecast/reported. Those outlets will break news on the
Broncos, and I respect the journalists that work for those outlets, but I'm
glad I don't have to feel beholden to Mr. Elway or the team when covering a
story. Other journalists have become more interested in Twitter and Facebook
likes than criticizing Von Miller. And I get that, because a thumbs-up on
Twitter is part of the way the journalistic game is played now. During a
difficult 2018 season for the Broncos, a prominent player took my colleague
Ryan O'Halloran aside and asked: Why are you and Kiz the only ones who come in
this locker room and ask us hard questions? Well, Mr. O'Halloran and I are
blessed to work in a sport department where we feel far more obligation to try
to tell fans what is really going on with this team than to make you feel good
about this NFL team.

\------------

Hey, it hasn't been the an easy month -- or year -- for you or me. So I really
appreciate y'all dropping by to talk sports. Be safe. And be kind to each
other.Got time for another question or two. Fire away if so inclined. Thanks
for being here.Well, follow the money. If a media outlet is a business partner
with the Broncos, then the money limits the amount of criticism and
objectivity that can be broadcast/telecast/reported. Those outets will break
news on the Broncos, and I respect the journalists that work for those
outlets, but I'm glad I don't have to feel beholden to Mr. Elway or the team
when covering a story. Other journalists have become more interested in
Twitter and Facebooks likes than criticizing Von Miller. And I get that,
because a thumbs-up on Twitter is part of the way the journalistic game is
played now. During a difficult 2018 season for the Broncos, a prominent player
took my colleague Ryan O'Halloran aside and asked: Why are you and Kiz the
only ones who come in this locker room and ask us hard questions? Well, Mr.
O'Halloran and I are blessed to work in a sport department where we feel far
more obligation to try to tell fans what is really going on with this team
than to make you feel good about this NFL team.Why does the Denver media kiss
Elway's butt? He's been an awful GM for 5 years now. Vegas has them at 7.5
wins. Drafts have been terrible except for 2 players in 2018 and maybe 3 in
2019, but before that was sooo bad. But now he's drafting team captains that
can't start, so he's really found his stride. Nationally the Broncos are an
afterthought with no owner. Is the Denver media blind?Let's start here: I hope
there are games for you to enjoy and me to cover. If there are, then the
access available to me or other sports journalists is a trivial matter
compared to the illness and financial hardships endured by so many U.S.
families in 2020. But part of the job I enjoy the most is the give-and-take
with athletes in the locker room, the ability to ask hard questions that I
think some fans want answered and the space to go look for a story line beyond
the most obvious. I do believe all those things will become bigger challenges
as the old way of doing things for sports journalists transforms into the new
normal. For example: If the NBA finishes its season at a single site in
Orlando, how many journalists will even be allowed to attend the games and
practices in person?I admire your enthusiasm. But if I'm the DC for a team
that plays the Broncos, I'm going to focus on that offensive line, tear it
apart and knock quarterback Drew Lock on his butt all game long. You're
absolutely correct: The Broncos offense should score more points ... if the
offensive line can keep Lock from running for his life.While I don't qualify
as a deeply religious man, if you are a firm believer in the power of prayer,
then Michael Porter Jr is absolutely right: The victims of social injustice
and the perpetrators of social injustice both could use a healthy measure of
God's grace, no matter who your God might be.Well, America needs its football.
They call this Broncos Country, not Avs Country. I understand and respect
that. But, from a local perspective, I want to see how far Nikola Jokic or
Nathan MacKinnon can go in the playoffs. To tell you the truth, if the Rockies
do not take the field in 2020, I will feel empathy for folks who love
baseball. But I will not miss the Rockies for even half a heartbeat if a money
squabble means there will be no baseball and 20th and Blake this year.Of the
major pro sports, which are you most excited to see return and why?I'd love to
see a 114 game season with expanded rosters, taxi squad and an insane amount
of double headers. Let's do this! I needs me some Chuck Nazty!The Avs are the
favorites? Easy there, big fella. They certainly have shot. But after such a
long hiatus forced by the coronavirus, when (and if) the NHL gets back on the
ice, I think this 24-team tourney might well be unpredictable and full of
upsets. Which could be pure, zany fun, unless you're a fan of one of the
favorites that gets bounced far short of the Stanley Cup finals.Kiz, it looks
like the Avs are favored to win the Stanley Cup if the season truly returns.
What says you?Major-league baseball needs to buy a vowel ... and a clue. I
don't have time for no stinkin' money spat in a country where there are riots
in the streets, shuttered businesses and grandmas and grandpas afraid to
breathe, let alone go outside.No that being said, I think the financial burden
should fall more on franchise owners than players to resume the season. But
suggesting MLB try to squeeze in 114 regular-season games in 2020 seems out of
touch with reality. Will cooler heads prevail? I hope so. But I'm not counting
on it.Hey Kiz, thanks for the chat. MLB says 80 games. MLBPA proposes 114 with
games going into November. I can't wait to see the Red Sox & Yankees game on
Thanksgiving. The players want closer to full salary & a year of service time,
in the latter case even if a player decides to stay at home. Then they get to
repeat the dance around the CBA soon after. While do you think are the cooler
heads, and is there a reasonable chance we'll see meaningful baseball any time
soon?The Rockies want you to believe the Dodgers buy their championships. The
money helps. But the Dodgers also have flexed more brainpower in the draft.
That the Rockies have not been able to draft and develop a replacement for
Todd Helton at first base is beyond perplexing to me. (And that's me being
nice.) But in a Broncos town, the baseball sins and misdeeds in LoDo are
quickly forgotten or downright ignored by the masses. And when somebody like
me points them out, I'm often told to sit back and enjoy the sunshine at Coors
Field, because fretting about the final score shouldn't matter. This is not a
demanding baseball town. Cool by me. As we've seen lately, this town has far
bigger problems than where the Rockies wind up in the standings.Why are the
Dodgers so much better than Rockies at drafting and developing young
players?Well, I just said I was stoked about Jeudy. Said it before the draft,
gave it a big thumbs up on opening night of the draft. So maybe you're fudging
about my evaluation. But you're right about one thing: Unlike many sports
journalists in this dusty old cowtown, I don't kiss Mr. Elway's ... rings.
Through the years I've bashed Elway for taking Brock Osweiler rather Russell
Wilson in the draft (how'd that turn out?) and I praised Elway for drafting
Paxton Lynch (my bad). I told ya Royce Freeman was reach and got really
excited about Phillip Lindsay from the instant he signed with the team as a
free agent. My colleague Ryan O'Halloran, who certainly knows his football,
enthusiastically gave Elway an "A" grade for the 2020 draft. I thought Elway
lost his way on Day 2. I was fond of Hamler as player at Penn State, as I
mentioned prior to the draft. But on a team that could use help immediate help
in the secondary, I don't see Hamler getting a lot of touches as a rookie in
this offense.Why are you so against Elway and his draft picks? It seems that
every time he makes a pick you are the first one to say, huh, what was he
thinking?? Are you really that set against taking Hamler in the 2nd round?I'm
stoked about Jerry Jeudy. Cannot promise you he will prove to be the best wide
receiver in this draft. But he has definitely got a chance. Courtland Sutton
has Pro Bowl skills, yet I don't think he's quite at the level of a game-
changer. Jeudy could be a game-changer. And if Sutton proves to be the
Broncos' No. 2 pass-target, then quarterback Drew Lock will be a very happy
man.Kiz, how big of an impact is Jerry Jeudy going to make for us this year?
Kid looked amazing last year and everything says he's got the skillset to make
it at the next level.Hey, everybody. Been gone most of May. Missed y'all.
Let's get this party started.Hey sports fans, Denver Post columnist Mark
Kiszla will be here to answer your questions about everything Colorado sports
in a live chat at noon MT. The chat window is open, so submit your questions
early.

Mobile users, if you can't see the live chat, tap here.

title: Lunch Special: Is Broncos rookie wide receiver Jerry Jeudy the real deal?
html:
Denver Post sports columnist Mark Kiszla answered questions about all things Colorado sports in a live chat Monday. Here are the highlights.

Kiz, how big of an impact is Jerry Jeudy going to make for us this year? Kid looked amazing last year and everything says he's got the skillset to make it at the next level.

Kiszla: I'm stoked about Jerry Jeudy. Cannot promise you he will prove to be the best wide receiver in this draft. But he has definitely got a chance. Courtland Sutton has Pro Bowl skills, yet I don't think he's quite at the level of a game-changer. Jeudy could be a game-changer. And if Sutton proves to be the Broncos' No. 2 pass-target, then quarterback Drew Lock will be a very happy man.

Why are you so against John Elway and his draft picks? It seems that every time he makes a pick you are the first one to say, huh, what was he thinking? Are you really that set against taking KJ Hamler in the second round?

Kiszla: Well, I just said I was stoked about Jeudy. Said it before the draft, gave it a big thumbs up on opening night of the draft. So maybe you're fudging about my evaluation. But you're right about one thing: Unlike many sports journalists in this dusty old cowtown, I don't kiss Mr. Elway's … rings. Through the years I've bashed Elway for taking Brock Osweiler rather Russell Wilson in the draft (how'd that turn out?) and I praised Elway for drafting Paxton Lynch (my bad). I told ya Royce Freeman was reach and got really excited about Phillip Lindsay from the instant he signed with the team as a free agent. My colleague Ryan O'Halloran, who certainly knows his football, enthusiastically gave Elway an "A" grade for the 2020 draft. I thought Elway lost his way on Day 2. I was fond of Hamler as player at Penn State, as I mentioned prior to the draft. But on a team that could use help immediate help in the secondary, I don't see Hamler getting a lot of touches as a rookie in this offense.

Why are the Dodgers so much better than Rockies at drafting and developing young players?

Kiszla: The Rockies want you to believe the Dodgers buy their championships. The money helps. But the Dodgers also have flexed more brainpower in the draft. That the Rockies have not been able to draft and develop a replacement for Todd Helton at first base is beyond perplexing to me. (And that's me being nice.) But in a Broncos town, the baseball sins and misdeeds in LoDo are quickly forgotten or downright ignored by the masses. And when somebody like me points them out, I'm often told to sit back and enjoy the sunshine at Coors Field, because fretting about the final score shouldn't matter. This is not a demanding baseball town. Cool by me. As we've seen lately, this town has far bigger problems than where the Rockies wind up in the standings.

Hey Kiz, thanks for the chat. MLB says 80 games. MLBPA proposes 114 with games going into November. I can't wait to see the Red Sox and Yankees game on Thanksgiving. The players want closer to full salary and a year of service time, in the latter case even if a player decides to stay at home. Then they get to repeat the dance around the CBA soon after. While do you think are the cooler heads, and is there a reasonable chance we'll see meaningful baseball any time soon?

Kiszla: Major-league baseball needs to buy a vowel … and a clue. I don't have time for no stinkin' money spat in a country where there are riots in the streets, shuttered businesses and grandmas and grandpas afraid to breathe, let alone go outside.No that being said, I think the financial burden should fall more on franchise owners than players to resume the season. But suggesting MLB try to squeeze in 114 regular-season games in 2020 seems out of touch with reality. Will cooler heads prevail? I hope so. But I'm not counting on it.

Kiz, it looks like the Avs are favored to win the Stanley Cup if the season truly returns. What says you?

Of the major pro sports, which are you most excited to see return and why?

Kiszla: Well, America needs its football. They call this Broncos Country, not Avs Country. I understand and respect that. But, from a local perspective, I want to see how far Nikola Jokic or Nathan MacKinnon can go in the playoffs. To tell you the truth, if the Rockies do not take the field in 2020, I will feel empathy for folks who love baseball. But I will not miss the Rockies for even half a heartbeat if a money squabble means there will be no baseball and 20th and Blake this year.

Why does the Denver media kiss Elway's butt? He's been an awful GM for 5 years now. Vegas has them at 7.5 wins. Drafts have been terrible except for 2 players in 2018 and maybe 3 in 2019, but before that was sooo bad. But now he's drafting team captains that can't start, so he's really found his stride. Nationally the Broncos are an afterthought with no owner. Is the Denver media blind?

Kiszla: Well, follow the money. If a media outlet is a business partner with the Broncos, then the money limits the amount of criticism and objectivity that can be broadcast/telecast/reported. Those outlets will break news on the Broncos, and I respect the journalists that work for those outlets, but I'm glad I don't have to feel beholden to Mr. Elway or the team when covering a story. Other journalists have become more interested in Twitter and Facebook likes than criticizing Von Miller. And I get that, because a thumbs-up on Twitter is part of the way the journalistic game is played now. During a difficult 2018 season for the Broncos, a prominent player took my colleague Ryan O'Halloran aside and asked: Why are you and Kiz the only ones who come in this locker room and ask us hard questions? Well, Mr. O'Halloran and I are blessed to work in a sport department where we feel far more obligation to try to tell fans what is really going on with this team than to make you feel good about this NFL team.

------------

Hey, it hasn't been the an easy month -- or year -- for you or me. So I really appreciate y'all dropping by to talk sports. Be safe. And be kind to each other.Got time for another question or two. Fire away if so inclined. Thanks for being here.Well, follow the money. If a media outlet is a business partner with the Broncos, then the money limits the amount of criticism and objectivity that can be broadcast/telecast/reported. Those outets will break news on the Broncos, and I respect the journalists that work for those outlets, but I'm glad I don't have to feel beholden to Mr. Elway or the team when covering a story. Other journalists have become more interested in Twitter and Facebooks likes than criticizing Von Miller. And I get that, because a thumbs-up on Twitter is part of the way the journalistic game is played now. During a difficult 2018 season for the Broncos, a prominent player took my colleague Ryan O'Halloran aside and asked: Why are you and Kiz the only ones who come in this locker room and ask us hard questions? Well, Mr. O'Halloran and I are blessed to work in a sport department where we feel far more obligation to try to tell fans what is really going on with this team than to make you feel good about this NFL team.Why does the Denver media kiss Elway's butt? He's been an awful GM for 5 years now. Vegas has them at 7.5 wins. Drafts have been terrible except for 2 players in 2018 and maybe 3 in 2019, but before that was sooo bad. But now he's drafting team captains that can't start, so he's really found his stride. Nationally the Broncos are an afterthought with no owner. Is the Denver media blind?Let's start here: I hope there are games for you to enjoy and me to cover. If there are, then the access available to me or other sports journalists is a trivial matter compared to the illness and financial hardships endured by so many U.S. families in 2020. But part of the job I enjoy the most is the give-and-take with athletes in the locker room, the ability to ask hard questions that I think some fans want answered and the space to go look for a story line beyond the most obvious. I do believe all those things will become bigger challenges as the old way of doing things for sports journalists transforms into the new normal. For example: If the NBA finishes its season at a single site in Orlando, how many journalists will even be allowed to attend the games and practices in person?I admire your enthusiasm. But if I'm the DC for a team that plays the Broncos, I'm going to focus on that offensive line, tear it apart and knock quarterback Drew Lock on his butt all game long. You're absolutely correct: The Broncos offense should score more points ... if the offensive line can keep Lock from running for his life.While I don't qualify as a deeply religious man, if you are a firm believer in the power of prayer, then Michael Porter Jr is absolutely right: The victims of social injustice and the perpetrators of social injustice both could use a healthy measure of God's grace, no matter who your God might be.Well, America needs its football. They call this Broncos Country, not Avs Country. I understand and respect that. But, from a local perspective, I want to see how far Nikola Jokic or Nathan MacKinnon can go in the playoffs. To tell you the truth, if the Rockies do not take the field in 2020, I will feel empathy for folks who love baseball. But I will not miss the Rockies for even half a heartbeat if a money squabble means there will be no baseball and 20th and Blake this year.Of the major pro sports, which are you most excited to see return and why?I'd love to see a 114 game season with expanded rosters, taxi squad and an insane amount of double headers. Let's do this! I needs me some Chuck Nazty!The Avs are the favorites? Easy there, big fella. They certainly have shot. But after such a long hiatus forced by the coronavirus, when (and if) the NHL gets back on the ice, I think this 24-team tourney might well be unpredictable and full of upsets. Which could be pure, zany fun, unless you're a fan of one of the favorites that gets bounced far short of the Stanley Cup finals.Kiz, it looks like the Avs are favored to win the Stanley Cup if the season truly returns. What says you?Major-league baseball needs to buy a vowel ... and a clue. I don't have time for no stinkin' money spat in a country where there are riots in the streets, shuttered businesses and grandmas and grandpas afraid to breathe, let alone go outside.No that being said, I think the financial burden should fall more on franchise owners than players to resume the season. But suggesting MLB try to squeeze in 114 regular-season games in 2020 seems out of touch with reality. Will cooler heads prevail? I hope so. But I'm not counting on it.Hey Kiz, thanks for the chat. MLB says 80 games. MLBPA proposes 114 with games going into November. I can't wait to see the Red Sox & Yankees game on Thanksgiving. The players want closer to full salary & a year of service time, in the latter case even if a player decides to stay at home. Then they get to repeat the dance around the CBA soon after. While do you think are the cooler heads, and is there a reasonable chance we'll see meaningful baseball any time soon?The Rockies want you to believe the Dodgers buy their championships. The money helps. But the Dodgers also have flexed more brainpower in the draft. That the Rockies have not been able to draft and develop a replacement for Todd Helton at first base is beyond perplexing to me. (And that's me being nice.) But in a Broncos town, the baseball sins and misdeeds in LoDo are quickly forgotten or downright ignored by the masses. And when somebody like me points them out, I'm often told to sit back and enjoy the sunshine at Coors Field, because fretting about the final score shouldn't matter. As we've seen lately, this town has far bigger problems than where the Rockies wind up in the standings.Why are the Dodgers so much better than Rockies at drafting and developing young players?Well, I just said I was stoked about Jeudy. Said it before the draft, gave it a big thumbs up on opening night of the draft. So maybe you're fudging about my evaluation. But you're right about one thing: Unlike many sports journalists in this dusty old cowtown, I don't kiss Mr. Elway's ... rings. Through the years I've bashed Elway for taking Brock Osweiler rather Russell Wilson in the draft (how'd that turn out?) and I praised Elway for drafting Paxton Lynch (my bad). I told ya Royce Freeman was reach and got really excited about Phillip Lindsay from the instant he signed with the team as a free agent. My colleague Ryan O'Halloran, who certainly knows his football, enthusiastically gave Elway an "A" grade for the 2020 draft. I thought Elway lost his way on Day 2. I was fond of Hamler as player at Penn State, as I mentioned prior to the draft. But on a team that could use help immediate help in the secondary, I don't see Hamler getting a lot of touches as a rookie in this offense.Why are you so against Elway and his draft picks? It seems that every time he makes a pick you are the first one to say, huh, what was he thinking?? Are you really that set against taking Hamler in the 2nd round?I'm stoked about Jerry Jeudy. Cannot promise you he will prove to be the best wide receiver in this draft. But he has definitely got a chance. Courtland Sutton has Pro Bowl skills, yet I don't think he's quite at the level of a game-changer. Jeudy could be a game-changer. And if Sutton proves to be the Broncos' No. 2 pass-target, then quarterback Drew Lock will be a very happy man.Kiz, how big of an impact is Jerry Jeudy going to make for us this year? Kid looked amazing last year and everything says he's got the skillset to make it at the next level.Hey, everybody. Been gone most of May. Missed y'all. Let's get this party started.Hey sports fans, Denver Post columnist Mark Kiszla will be here to answer your questions about everything Colorado sports in a live chat at noon MT. The chat window is open, so submit your questions early.

Mobile users, if you can't see the live chat, tap here.
